section: Exercise 4.4.3: Using the k-to-1 rule for counting ways to line up a group.
instructions:
Ten kids line up for recess. The names of the kids are:

{Abe, Ben, Cam, Don, Eli, Fran, Gene, Hal, Ike, Jan}.

Let S be the set of all possible ways to line up the kids. For example, one ordering might be:

(Fran, Gene, Hal, Jan, Abe, Don, Cam, Eli, Ike, Ben)

The names are listed in order from left to right, so Fran is at the front of the line and Ben is at the end of the line.

Let T be the set of all possible ways to line up the kids in which Gene is ahead of Don in the line. Note that Gene does not have to be immediately ahead of Don. For example, the ordering shown above is an element in T.

Now define a function f whose domain is S and whose target is T. Let x be an element of S, so x is one possible way to order the kids. If Gene is ahead of Don in the ordering x, then f(x) = x. If Don is ahead of Gene in x, then f(x) is the ordering that is the same as x, except that Don and Gene have swapped places.
question:
(e)

Let Q be the set of orderings in which Gene comes before Don and Jan comes before Abe (again, not necessarily immediately before). Define a k-to-1 correspondence from S to Q. Use the value of k to determine |Q|.
answer:
Define a function g: S → Q. For x ∈ S, if Don comes before Gene in x, then swap Gene and Don. If Abe comes before Jan in x, then swap Abe and Jan. Otherwise make no changes to x.

The function g is a 4-to-1 correspondence. For a particular y ∈ Q, there are at least 4 line-ups that map to y: the line-up y itself, the line-up y with Don and Gene swapped, the line-up y with Abe and Jan swapped, and the line-up y with Don and Gene swapped and Abe and Jan swapped.

Consider a line-up y ∈ Q. Let i and j be the place in line of Gene and Don. (Gene is in the i th place and Don is in the j th place.) Then i < j. Similarly, let k and l be the place in line of Jan and Abe (Jan is in the k th place and Abe is in the l th place.) Then k < l. There are exactly four line-ups in which Don and Gene occupy locations from {i, j} and Jan and Abe occupy locations from {k, l}. The function g does not change the set of locations occupied by Don and Gene or the set of locations occupied by Jan and Abe. The function g also does not change the location in line of any of the other kids. Therefore the function g maps at most 4 line-ups in S to a single line-up in Q.

There is a 4-to-1 correspondence from S to Q. Therefore |Q| = |S|/4 = 3628800/4 = 907200.
